pros: Provides geat experience for industry. IT director and team will protect you from customer service backlash. Training modules are in place to give a framework on what to do. If you're proactive, you will be considered to move up to take on greater responsibility beyond help desk tasks depending on your personal career goals. Eg writing software deployment scripts, auditing, documentation, training/mentoring, servicing specialized IT tasks for faculty.
cons: For a position in the university, there's never room to negotiate a raise.

review_title: University pays poverty level wages; is bloated with useless people making 6 figures
pros: There is no strict dress code, which means it is easy to look presentable with very little effort.
cons: Terrible pay. I make less than half of what it takes to rent an awful studio in a bad neighborhood. Dozens of people with the words "dean" or "director" in their title who take over $100k a year of tuition dollars from students and do nothing to contribute to the success of the university or its students. CSUS pays poverty level wages to its staff and wastes millions of dollars every year hiring people whose salaries are unjustifiable. Why does every college within the university need multiple deans or directors who do student assistant level work? Our deans act as hall monitors who spend their days being unproductive and counting the minutes until you are back from a break. Most fast food places in California pay more than CSUS does, and at least at a fast food place you get discounted food. Benefits are horrible here, the unions are ineffective and condescending, and I use about 10% of my monthly income for prescriptions alone. Opportunities for advancement are abysmal. I was propositioned to take a promotion which would have entailed 2x-4x more work, but was only offered 0.25% greater pay. When I started here they told me they do not negotiate salaries, even though I had years of relevant experience and previous experience working here. This place is full of terrible leadership who use their positions as a safety net for them to do nothing and get paid for it. Ineffective and verbally abusive faculty are promoted to associate dean, then promoted to dean; while simultaneously protecting sexual predators who have a documented history of harassing students. Or how about directors who were let go from UC Berkeley for being terrible at their job, only to get a very similar position at CSUS. What a great message, that we will take people who were deemed not fit for employment at notable schools. It is safe to say that if someone is a dean or director at CSUS, that they are probably terrible at their job and in no way justify the salary they take from the university.

pros:
Good state benefits (health/ dental/ vision insurance, reasonable employer retirement contributions/ early retirement options, etc.) even for lecturers, commitment to excellence in teaching, a diverse campus, good leadership (especially President Nelsen who is exceptionally good in communication and handling difficult situations), mostly small classes, faculty development opportunities (especially for new tenure-track faculty), good collegiality, and recently increasing number of graduate and certificate programs.
Note: You need to revise President /CEO information in your questionnaire.
cons: Teaching and service expectations are high as it is mainly a four-year teaching institution. There are limited resources for grading help and extensive research projects unless some grants are acquired (to fund research related expenses or to get release time). Administrative assistants are usually fine but some of them are either lazy or unqualified and not much can be done about it. Faculty salaries are relatively low (despite good benefits) but would hopefully get better during post-Covid19 era.

pros: This is a very supportive institution that fosters the well being of the entire student.

review_title: Incivility and disregard to part-time faculty
pros: The University is mandated to adhere to employees rights as per collective bargaining agreement. It is great to work for this university for retirement and health insurance are available.
cons: It seems that the hiring is behind doors focuses if you are a graduate of the university or of any Californian university. Other graduates get treated as lower class citizens. It is strange as the majority of student body are children of immigrants but faculty are California graduates.  There is the culture of disrespect of part-time faculty at least in one of the sciences department. Do not believe what they tell you in the interview that you will be re-hired, they do not walk the talk and they try to save money by hiring own graduates. Tenured faculty make scientific mistakes and a part-time faculty is not allowed to correct mistakes. No academic freedom or even first amendment right to speak! Many faculty have been at this university as "part-time lecturers" for over ten years, that is unreal. Look for a progressive job elsewhere that allow you to progress in your career. Save yourself lots of humiliation   and do not work for this university.

pros: Works well with students schedules.

review_title: Beautifully Landscaped Campus, Terribly Low Staff Salaries
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator in Sacramento, CA
pros: The benefits provided are quite good, and if you have accumulated any years of experience as a State of California employee, you bring those with you and can accumulate more vacation and sick leave time. There are many places on campus to eat, and there is always some interesting event to attend.
cons: Staff salaries are far lower on this campus than at other CSUs, and far below what you would be paid for a comparable job at the State, at a community college or in the private sector. While there are training opportunities on-line and on-campus, staff rarely will be given the time to avail themselves of it. Transferring between departments is quite difficult and most new positions are hired as Temporary, leaving you with no real security. Employees have to pay to park on-campus, despite the meager wages they receive. General campus morale is poor and there is little camaraderie or support between departments, colleges and administrative offices. Many managers have terrific skills in political maneuvering, but far less ability in managing staff effectively.

pros: Working for an institution of higher education with a diverse student body feels better than churning out widgets for Evil Corp. Information Technology is largely centralized and appears to be appropriately funded, with ongoing efforts to improve efficiency, communication, and service delivery. There are definitely some passionate people to work with.
cons:
There seem to be leadership issues at higher levels that trickle down through the organization, resulting in a politicized atmosphere with some stagnation and fear of making mistakes. That said, there seems to be support for implementing best practices and frameworks (like ITIL), which help to cut through some of these issues. 

Possibly related to pension and unionized employees, there are definitely some "old timers" and pension seekers doing the minimum to get through to the day they vest, which can be a drag on passionate employees. 

In central IT at least, positions are siloed with limited scope of responsibility and room for growth. It is easy for employees to say that something is "not their problem", when they could definitely contribute to a solution.

pros:
It is a nice working environment. There are a lot of nice and intellectual people there and the Center is a place where tutors can hang out, do their homework, or socialize with other tutors in the staff room in between classes, even when they are not on duty.
The Supervisors are very helpful and when there is an issue (for example: a tutor is having trouble making progress with a student), they are more than happy to give advice and help in anyway.
cons:
One of the cons is that to work at the Writing Center is that you have to take the class the semester before.
Another con about this position is the number of hours they give the students. It ranges from each semester from 3 to 5 hours a week depending on how many tutors are employed and how much money the department have to pay the tutors.

job_title: IT In Central IRT Org in Sacramento, CA
pros: Benefits are really good.  Salary is okay, but not competitive with private sector.
cons: Constantly shifting priorities, too much work for understaffed organization, unrealistic expectations. Performance reviews are not constructive, but are used by management as a "stick" to punish discourage employees.  Morale is very low.  Haven't had real raises in over 10 years, despite budget increases. Overwhelming number of managers have never read a management book, taken a course on organizational behavior, or necessarily understand their role. There is a steady turnover of younger employees who move on to better jobs. Employees are retiring early because they are fed up.  Most people I work with hate their job, hate their boss, and just try to stay under the radar.

review_title: I enjoyed working for CSU Sacramento. As a concurrent student, it provided an ideal and convenient environment.
pros: The university provides ample job stability, vacation time, and lots of opportunity for intellectual and personal growth through the tuition waiver program for staff.
cons: Standard suite of tensions between managers and staff, as well as a substantial amount of bureaucracy that needs to be maneuvered through in order to accomplish job tasks and duties. Efficiency appears to be lacking at times in conjunction with a lack of positive or generative office culture.

job_title: Information Technology Consultant in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great benefits, free tuition, great if you're family oriented because they allow time to tend to your family if needed. My department allows me to further my career if I need to.
cons: No room for growth, the pay sucks and ITCs pay scale is all over the board, no consistency. You can find someone with an ITC classification making close to six figures while you'll see some barely pushing 50k a year. Be prepared to do mandatory volunteering over the weekend.

review_title: If you like to phone it in. This place is for you.
pros:
Excellent benefits (retirement, health insurance, fee waiver to attend college, etc.)
Hours are good (rarely more than 40 hours per week)
Low expectations mean low stress most of the time.
cons:
Filthy facilities.
Incompetent management (and too many of them).
Little respect or support for employees.
No chance for promotion / raises.
Most employees put as little effort as possible into their work and are often not knowledgeable within their field.

review_title: Opportunity If You Like a Challenge
pros: There are few rules and the ones that exist are easily broken.  Massively overbuilt IT infrastructure.  Fantastic if you're savvy enough to gain assets and access.
cons: There are few rules and the ones that exist are easily broken.  Read somewhere "Sac State is a best-of European Feudalism & Indian Caste Society."  Very hierarchical to put it mildly.  Nice if you're on the upside, huge drain if your'e on the bottom.

job_title: Information Technology Consultant in Sacramento, CA
pros: The student development is the best. All the Boss care about your future and giving you the experience and knowledge you will need to go into the work force. The hours are very flexible to accommodate your class your are taking.
cons: Training was lacking for some students. If you had someone who was very knowledge and was a good trainer you would be well off. If you didn't it was like being thrown into a fire and hopefully you can work your way out/

pros: There are a lot of wonderful people employed at the University. Overall, the workplace is positive and fun. Training opportunities are available depending on the state of the budget.
cons: State employment means lower salaries than private employment. Advancement is slow or non-existent because of that. Employees are asked to personally financially sacrifice for campus expansions/upgrades.

review_title: The experience definitely depends on the quality and chemistry of the placement.
pros: This program is a great opportunity to work at the highest levels of California state government. There is a lot of respect for the programs in Sacramento, and it gives you a high level of credibility to have the fellowship's stamp of approval.  This is by far the best way to get a job in the Building, if that's what you're looking for.
cons: The program administration is terrible, and office placements are erratic - some are amazing, some are pretty average.

review_title: Served as Administrator of a new research center.
pros: Enjoyed working in a campus environment. Particularly found the students to be an invigorating  part of the work.
cons: Faculty are often lone eagles who do their own thing on their own terms. This made it very difficult to forge cooperation and collaboration with some of them in order to achieve research goals. Also, multiple rounds of budget cuts from the state created a very difficult fiscal environment, which negatively affected morale.

pros: My internship as a Staff Writer with Sac State was a positive experience. They give you the chance to prove yourself. All yo have to do is sign up and your basically immediately on the Staff.
cons: A lot of work. Can't take too many classes while also doing this internship. It was a rewarding experience though. I tried taking 21 units and doing it, which didn't work out.

job_title: Student Services Professional in Sacramento, CA
pros:
Great people, great staff, great students
Diverse student body
Beautiful campus
Dedicated student-centered employees, especially in Student Affairs
cons:
Faculty are not diverse enough--still too many white males!
Unflexible schedules for staff
Limited opportunities for growth due to CA state budget crisis
Union controlled raises for staff--union hasn't negotiated a raise for staff in over 4 years
Business model in an educational setting 
Very little staff recognition by management

review_title: Fine but needs better Adjunct pay
pros: The faculty and staff are fantastic and help in any way they can. Immediate staff are extremely responsive. Students can be engaged and making a difference in their lives is rewarding.
cons:
Administrative oversight is immense. It's impossible to make change happen for the lowest rung of employees. 

Entrance qualifications are low and it can feel like teaching high school at times.

pros: Convenient with your classes and for you to put something on your resume.
cons: The pay sucks. The IT Department never gives any raises to their students and its incredibly frustrating when students in Facilities are getting yearly raises. Some managers are very political and horrible people in general. The pay disparity between students and some staff is ridiculous, a Google search of their salaries is easily found and it just ticks you off on how little they pay you.

review_title: Best Higher Ed Employer in Sacramento Region
pros: Exciting work environment that is student focused. Very diversified student population and services to support student success. No two days are the same.  Plenty of programs and committee work to stay involved and make a difference. Employees who go the extra mile are often recognized.
cons: Pay can be low for some classifications and budget cuts make it hard to get necessary resources to do a better job serving students.

pros: The faculty was wonderful in the Bio department.  Many professors were quite interested in their students, and quite a few were heads of special groups or clubs.
cons: The workload can be a bit demanding, and difficult to juggle with full-time classes.  Even so, most faculty members were quite understanding when finals/midterms were coming.  Days could be taken off at these times to study.

pros: Overall good professors, nice campus, regular university improvements, health and wellness proactive, campus involvement opportunity excellent, foodservice good, beautiful outdoor location..
cons: Student network of assistance through campus run programs poor, student overall attitude and commitment to supportive and engaging peer associations poor, targeting on campus high, opportunities to find answers and support in certain areas low, some professors can target and act in negative immature manner as well.

pros: Staff and faculty genuinely care about students, and the vast majority work many more hours than people realize to make this place run smoothly.
cons: Politics of the state capitol and "state worker mentality" are sometimes an issue -- it would be nice if everyone wanted to serve the students with positive energy - without the students, we would not be here!

pros: Benefits, high earning potential, coworkers, nice campus
cons: management, leadership. University methods, decisions, and employer perception are often counter intuitive, illogical, and prioritize administrative employees, and the perception of the university, and often neglects, or outright weakens, the strength, and effectiveness of custodial, and maintenance staff.

pros: Proximity to SF and SLT, cheap rent and mortgages, depressed real estate market, every outdoor recreational activity imaginable, if you like hot it's for you!
cons: Zero recognition for doing more than what is required, no incentive to accept more responsibility, some inept leaders, way too hot!!

review_title: There are worse places to work
pros: Good benefits, friendly staff and student population, beautiful campus with lots of green areas.
cons: low pay, staff often work outside of classification, disparity in staff/management salary, merit pay  approved but never funded, pay to park.

review_title: It was an experience of learning techiniques, utilizing and gaining skills, and a great team environment.
job_title: Summer Research Faculty in Sacramento, CA
pros: SEE is a team based environment with a small well-rounded staff. They accept new ideas and improvements to old ones, and individuals are treated with respect, regardless of position. They are also very community based.
cons: There is a small staff and not a lot of room to move up.

pros: The California State University of Sacramento has a great nursing program. The clinical rotations are completed within some of Sacramento's best hospitals.
cons: Currently the nursing program is impacted. However, the field of nursing although has ample job opportunities getting hired as  new graduate is also difficult.

job_title: Director of Public Relations Management and Planning Class in Sacramento, CA
pros: I had an incredible experience working with many different types of people including working with different leadership styles, personalities and communication styles. I had the opportunity to be the follower in classes when in my first two years but as I learned more and grew more confident in my own leadership skills, I took on several leadership positions.
cons: Sometimes the buildings lacked ventilation and were over heated during the winter.

review_title: Great place to work for college students.
pros: The best reason to work at Services to Students with Disabilities is the ability to interact with a diverse people.
cons: The downside of working at Services to Students with Disabilities is that the compensation and room to grow is low.

pros:
Free Rent/ Priority Registration was worth it.
Meet Lots of People
Become more outgoing
Develop Strong relationships
Great Culture
Friendly Environment
cons:
Politics play a major part in this place
Have basically no social life/ Life is pretty much being an RA

review_title: Horrible Place to work for Those that are not students
pros: Working with the students was a plus and the benefits were good.  Those are the only pros for an otherwise terrible experience.
cons: Administration and horribly bad management and HR. Unsafe working conditions, university has been sued by employees and lost.  Pay is below market and raises are difficult.

job_title: Health Surveyor Call Ctr in Sacramento, CA
pros: Worthy cause.  A good place to work for 4 hours at a time; who can read word-for-word for 8 hours?!  Fewer hours improves the quality of calls, and you will enjoy the work more. Great  20 hours/wk job for students as the callers at $13/hr.
cons:
Must read word-for-word.  At the interview, they say you can build rapport with callers but you really can't.  Students who have been there for a while OFTEN agree with callers which introduces bias, but they've been there a while so they are not checked as often.
Many students working there have a poor work ethic, unprofessional language, but a few students are very responsible.  Many are good friends, so they do not report each other when not on task.  LOTS of students using personal phones during work hours--approved by management--students are talking with friends!   Some even log each other out or/and in for work!  The managers say they cannot do any better--I say they can if they just make a few changes--and help those students in the process.

job_title: Receptionist At the WELL in Sacramento, CA
pros:
- Network with students, staff, and faculty
- Build leadership skills
- Attend training session to better yourself in college
- Friendly and motivating environment
- All of the pro-staff wants you to succeed in college (they emphasis you focus more on school than work)
- You will gain an amazing college experience!
cons: - There is nothing bad working here.

pros: Great team and management. Very easy approach, and very forgiving supervisors. Flexible hours and ability to work very little time per day.
cons: Traffic to CSU Sacramento is bad. Constant problem with parking. Sometimes you have to drive only to work for one hour but that depends on your class schedule.

job_title: Junior Conference Planner in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great for those who like to work independently. They push you to grow yourself professionally and strive for your goals.
cons: Low pay, Low pay, Low Pay.

job_title: Front Desk Attendant in Sacramento, CA
pros: Its a job on campus
cons: Resident Life Coordinators (RLCs) have favorites and upper administrators are incapable of accomplishing things in a timely manner.

pros: Love all of my co-workers. We all stand together in a collective love for learning and helping other reach their goals and professional dreams.
cons: Not many promotional opportunities and low pay for the amount of work required.

pros: The benefits are great, pretty campus...
cons: Low pay, no opportunities for advancement (frequently turning down promoting internal candidates in favor of external candidates), no reward for doing a good job so it makes people pretty unmotivated and apathetic about their jobs.

pros: Convenient to work on campus - no commuting. Flexible hours and professors always allow time off to study when needed. Not very challenging.
cons: Low pay, low hours. You are limited to working a total of 20 hours. Good for learning, bad for paying for rent.

review_title: The campus is one of the best things about CSU Sacramento
pros:
Around  a lot of people. 
Networking on a Campus level.
Everything you need is on campus.
Face to face time with other employees
cons:
Around students, sometimes feels like high school.
Drama
Staying at your desk and not moving around
Some places are dead end jobs

review_title: Great company with a lot of opportunities for development
pros: Development opportunities, large staff of peers, administration listens to employees and accepts feedback
cons: part time work with the only opportunities for full time are post grad

job_title: Conference and Training Services Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros: great people to work with and lot of opportunities to learn and grow professionally, good starter job out of college, beautiful campus, close to home
cons: getting paid once a month, paying for parking when you don't get paid that well and its not guaranteed.

review_title: Student Affairs has some of the best people to work with
pros: Great people, awesome way to gain experience in higher education, and gives you an opportunity to learn a lot about the intricacies regarding the administrative side of higher education/university.
cons: The yearly raises are minimal; depends on your bargaining unit/union.

pros: Plenty of time to tend school matters, teaching students subjects that are important to your current studies and decent pay
cons: Unorganized at points but that can be fixed easily

pros: Flexible work schedule that makes going to school and working less stressful.
cons: I think that there should be more room for advancement towards salary positions.

pros: -Had my own office which is rare for part time faculty
cons: -Very little training. I had never taught before and we only had a 2 hour meeting the day before the semester started to prepare & ask questions!

pros: Very accommodating to your school schedule. Do need to make sure you stand up for yourself. It can be somewhat busy during certain months depending on your department.
cons: Sometimes feel like I wasn’t taken seriously as a student assistant; 20 hours max

review_title: Great work while going to school
pros:
Easily go from class to work
Relaxed environment
More involved in campus life
Good pay for a student
Flexible with schedule
cons:
Its a government job, so some people are not motivated
Technology is outdated for the most part

review_title: Front Desk Student Assistant in the Health and Wellness Promotion
job_title: Front Desk Student Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros:
- Super Chill
- Works around your schedule
- Clerical work
cons: One person there will suck. Thinks he/she knows it all ( I mean he/she kinda does but still sucks)

pros: Loved working on campus because my hours were set around my class schedule. It was nice knowing that once I left campus I was done. Made traveling convenient and the pay was great.
cons: Getting paid once a month

review_title: A good experience for a transition between graduating and finding a start to your career.
pros: Wonderful people to learn from and work with, also nice facilities that you are able to use.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement.

pros: I love students very much and they like my family
cons: I got my master in mechanical with 3.97GPA in 1993 and then suffered a stroke to a disable.

pros: Great Experience and get chance to work with faculty on their research and gain work experience and recommendation letters which helps in full-time jobs after graduation
cons: No benefits offered just the hourly pay

pros: Great people. Everyone is kind and fun to work with
cons: Budgets constantly get cut and makes it hard to produce any quality work. Very little room for advancement

review_title: Set up for events at the University Union
pros: The job is very flexible with your school schedule.
cons: Night shifts can last all night depending on the amount of work

pros: laid back, friendly staff. I wasn't a paid employee so I cannot comment on the benefits or pay of the organization. but I enjoyed my time there.
cons: Lots of after hours work.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Sacramento, CA
pros:
- Team-oriented
- Customer driven and Student focused
cons: - Some departments can be very politic on  how they want to run their department and who gets to make the decision

pros:
Flexible Schedules
Convenient Location
Decent Pay
Friendly Staff
Career Advancement Opportunities
cons:
Politics
Pretentious Managerial Staff
No benefit plans
Micromanagement
No fluidity between apartments

review_title: Camera operator for Sacramento State Athletics
pros: Great work experience getting to learn how cameras work and how to capture pristine images/ video for our athletics page.
cons: long hours on your feet

pros: Its on campus and if you're a student, its really convenient.
cons: No raises for students (ESPECIALLY IN IRT) when I hear when other students in other departments get raises.

pros:
- friendly co-workers
-get to meet lots of different people from the programs
-easy to balance school and work
cons: -higher management takes a long time to decide things

pros: The best two jobs and two bosses I ever had, during my entire work life.
cons: That the jobs couldn't last forever

pros: Excellent Work Place, Lots to Learn, People are friendly and  help you learn things along with school work
cons: nothing to state as con

pros: Great flexibility and independence in professional growth
cons: Easily get bogged down in teaching with not have enough resources

pros: Everyone is nice at the Math Lab, the schedule assigned is according to your school schedule.
cons: Requires to take a 3 units class

pros: Good pay, great work culture makes it less stressful for students to balance studies and part-time job.
cons: None that I know of

job_title: Hardware Support Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros: It is on campus, work is interesting and a good pace.
cons: hours can become carce and you are paid monthly.

pros: Affordable health benefits for the entire family!
cons: Traffic in and around the campus can be challenging during the school terms.

Great management with a helpful attitude.
Good school and work balance.
cons: It is a student job salary.

pros: great, hardworking students and faculty
cons: significant cutbacks and economic challenges

pros: friendly management and a relaxing position.
cons: can be boring and can get lonely.

pros: Easy to work with, flexible scheduling
cons: No real office spaces available to tutors. Random spaces.

job_title: Terminal Lounge/Gallery Attendant in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great flexibility with school class schedule
cons: Low pay but that's to be expected of a student job.

pros: Best part time job because it feels like you are working with family.
cons: No cons about working there.

pros: They have Flexible hours and Great people to work with

job_title: Instructional Student Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros: Tutoring was a great way to advance current skills.
cons: The hours were set by the department.

pros: Everyone is friendly and supportive,
